entry.title: Re: ABAP in ADT – Missing Variable Templates and Alternatives?
entry.content:
Okay, let me explain better with example.

I imagine the usage like this. Lets say I have following APPEND statment that I use often.

APPEND VALUE #( group       = 'C'
                number      = 500
                description = `Group C-2` ) TO initial_data.

In my current Eclipse ADT I can define template like this

APPEND VALUE #( group = '${group}' 
                number = ${number)
                description = `${desc}`) TO ${table}.
${cursor}

When template is trigered, I can jump between the ${} variables using Tab. The current template allows me to generate the base structure, but

  • I have to change ${table} variable every time.  
  • I can't list relevant options for Ctrl+Space to choose from (Assume that group field has only few options).

Assuming that I work with initial_data frequently, and have predefined options for group field, I would like to enhance my template like this

APPEND VALUE #( group = '${options:{A,B,C}}' 
                number = ${number)
                description = `${desc}`) TO ${default:initial_table}.
${cursor}

This template should allow me to

  • Jump between ${}
  • When inside ${options:{A,B,C}}, I can get suggestion from Ctrl+Space to fill listed values inside the brackets.
  • The initial_table is filled automatically, however I can override it when I want to 

 I found this usage for other programing languages (like Java), however the ADT extension does not provide such keywords for templates (Note that I dont know the exact keyword (option,  default), these serves only as a demonstration of what i want to do).

Hopefully this clarifies my intentions.

entry.title: Procurement process Brazil
entry.content:
Hello All,

We have a specific requirement where I would need inputs from bright minds out there. 

Plant 1000: Demand is created in plant from different sources.

Plant 1001: No procurement to be done from this plant. This plant will hold stock and supply to plant 1000.

Scenario:

Demand created in plant 1000, if stock is in plant 1001, then it should be supplied to plant 1000 from 1001 (Stock transfer scheduling agreement) else material should be procured from supplier into 1001 using purchase scheduling agreement.  

In purchase scheduling agreement, delivery address could be of plant 1001. When supplier ships, ASN in SAP to create inbound delivery  within plant 1000 but physically goods are going to plant 1001 directly.  Inbound delivery when goods receipted into 1000 should trigger automatic transfer of goods from 1000 to 1001 plant with exact same information ( STO scheduling agreement - > OBD -> IBD). The GR is done in 1001 plant using Inbound delivery document.

When a demand is created in plant 1000, stock from plant 1001 is transferred to 1000 else stock sits in plant 1000.

Here, we have requirement to hold stock in plant 1001 and on demand can be sent to plant 1000 but plant 1001 is not to perform any procurement.

Kindly suggest how this can be achieved in standard SAP or how it can be done with custom development.

Regards,

Arvind

entry.title: The Buyer’s Choice? It’s SAP BTP!
entry.content:
It’s been another great year for reviews of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) on the Trust Radius review platform. Having received the coveted Top Rated award earlier this year, we’re now preparing to step out in style next year having also recently been awarded with the Trust Radius Buyer’s Choice award for 2026.

Of course, we rely entirely on our wonderful customers to win awards like this, as they are the ones who are kind enough to share their thoughts and experiences in the reviews they write about us.  Awards are then given based on assessment of review submissions, and with qualification for the Buyer’s Choice award being made on the basis that 75% of customer reviews rate products as best in capabilities, value for price, and customer relationship, we know that we’re getting something right. And our prize for this, is a new badge to add to our growing collection.

 

A variety of experiences shared in the form of unique reviews

Customers familiar with the Trust Radius review submission form will know that this follows a set question structure, however the way in which customers respond is always different, depending upon their own system landscape and unique business needs. The result is an extensive list of reviews which describe how customers use SAP BTP in a variety of ways, from integration to user experience, to clean core among others.

Here are some examples of the most recent use cases:

  • Extensibility using SAP BTP to build a SoD software for SAP ERP (15 Nov ‘25)
  • Clean core extensions using modern low code tools on SAP Build (15 Nov ‘25)
  • App development used to build an AI-enabled Promotion Management App (14 Nov ‘25)
  • Integrate & extend to create user interfaces and extensions for SAP SuccessFactors across onboarding and recruitment modules (14 Nov ‘25)
  • Integration with SAP and non-SAP systems (7 Nov ’25)
  • Integrate & automate to help streamline operations and automate repetitive tasks (7 Nov ’25)

And this is just a small sample of the 71 reviews that customers have left in the last month alone, but which serve to show how SAP BTP is used to meet the different needs of customers across lines of business and industries, whether in SAP- or hybrid-solution landscapes.

If you’re interested to read more, then I’d recommend that you take a look at the SAP BTP review page on Trust Radius, where you’ll find all current reviews listed – and you can filter to view those most relevant to you. And if you use SAP BTP in your company, and you’re inclined, I’d also welcome you to leave a review whilst you’re there too, so that you can share your own experience with others.

Happy reading!

Chris Grundy, Product Marketing, SAP BTP

entry.title: Re: BW Note Validation in SAC: Instantly see whether your BW backend is up to date
entry.content:
Hi Michael, 

It will use the SAC wave version of the tenant it is run on. So it checks the difference from preview tenant to backend. 

It does not check which notes are missing in particular, it only calculates how many QRC/SP notes are missing. This is just a general hint for the story developer if the backend system is on par with the frontend. 

Best regards, 
Sajoscha

entry.title: Re: Procurement process Brazil
entry.content:
Some standard options are

1. MRP Area / Special Procurement Key
Define a special procurement key for materials in Plant 1000:

  • First source: Stock transfer from Plant 1001.
  • Second source: External procurement (vendor).

This way, MRP in Plant 1000 will first check 1001 stock, and if insufficient, trigger external procurement. Procurement proposals (Purchase Scheduling Agreement) are created in Plant 1000, but delivery address can be set to Plant 1001. But the limitation is the inbound delivery will be created for Plant 1001 (since that’s the delivery address). You’d need custom logic if you want the inbound delivery technically in 1000 but physically received in 1001.

2. Stock Transport Orders with Scheduling Agreements
Maintain STO Scheduling Agreement between 1001 → 1000. When demand arises in 1000, system checks 1001 stock and creates STO. If stock is not available, MRP in 1000 triggers external procurement. Supplier delivers to 1001, and then you manually or automatically trigger STO to move stock to 1000. But here, the limitation is the “automatic transfer” from 1000 to 1001 after GR is not standard. You’d need enhancement.

3. Vendor → Plant 1001 Direct Delivery with Cross‑Docking
Supplier delivers directly to Plant 1001. You configure cross‑docking / direct stock transfer so that inbound delivery in 1001 automatically generates an STO to 1000. This requires custom BAdI / enhancement because standard SAP does not automatically create STO after GR

entry.title: Re: Asset depreciation need to reverse from sunset date (...
entry.content:
Hi ,

Option A : 

  • Go to T-Code: AS02 (Change Asset Master).
  • Select the asset and company code.
  • In the Depreciation Areas tab:
    • Change the Depreciation Key to 0000 (No Depreciation).
  • Save the changes. Impact: Depreciation will not be calculated going forward                                                                         Option B
  • Go to T code : AS05 Block the asset master 
  •  it will only block the asset for further acquisition but all other activiites like retirement, transfer & depreciation can be done

entry.title: How to build an AI side by side extension for Fieldglass
entry.content:
In this blog post, we’ll walk you through building a side-by-side extension that combines SAP BTP’s AI capabilities with Fieldglass to streamline external worker onboarding. Using a practical example, we demonstrate how to create an intelligent document validation system that automatically reviews content of worker documents (ID, criminal records, debt collection statements, and confidentiality agreements) against company guidelines. The AI-powered extension extracts key content from documents, validates it using large language models, and presents summarized findings to end users for final approval or rejection decisions. This approach with GenAI Hub to protect these sensitive information significantly reduces manual review time while ensuring compliance, with all decisions automatically documented back in Fieldglass for complete audit trails.

In this example we test with for types of documents:

  • ID
  • Debt collection
  • Criminal record
  • Confidential agreement

Architecture:

Document AI: Service to retrieve the information from the different types of documents. For each document there is a specific schema defined

HANA Cloud: Stores all the needed data for the workflow/UI. Possibility to compare document to reference document. Also stores the guidelines that are used to check the entries from the documents

SAP AI Core: Access to the different LLMs. Used to decide if the entries found with Document AI are acceptable per guideline or not. Summarizes the findings for the end user and gives recommendation

Destination Service: Stores the credentials for OAuth2 and other relevant API data to access SAP Fieldglass from the CAP application. You need to generate an API key for Fieldglass (sap help documentation)

Process Flow:

Here is a very basic overview of the process flow of the application:

 

We retrieve all workorders from Fieldglass and for all new ones we also retrieve the documents. If all documents are available for a work order we start the validation process. Validated will be ID (Name, birthday), confidential agreement (signed not signed), debt collection and credit statement are checked for entries. Results are validated over AI Core based on company guidelines. Resulting summary of findings are being displayed in the Fiori App to decide. The decision is then being sent over API to Fieldglass with a approval comment or a reject reason. The decision is being documented in Fieldglass. For each document type there is an Activity Item which has the verification setting enabled so we can accept, reject it

User interface:

The user can see the summary of the users entries, the current item being validated and the items that already have been validated. The user can also look up the original document to cross check the summary if needed.
 

APIs and endpoints:

Fieldglass APIs:

The Fieldglass APIs are, to be honest, not that straight forward 😉

For this example we used the following APIs:

  • Activity Item Completion Upload (help, API docu)
    • To set the status of the Fieldglass Activity Items as Rejected, Completed or Verify and with the reject reason/comment
  • Work Order Delta Download (help, API docu)
    • For retrieving all the work orders. Be aware this gets you a delta since the last call! Not all Work orders
  • Worker from Work Order Download (help, API doc)
    • Fetch all information of the worker (name, security level etc.)
  • Attachment XML Download (help, <no API available in business accelerator hub)
    • For retrieving all relevant documents from a specific work order
    • Parameters need to be set like the following
      • ?object_ref=Activity Item~${workOrderID}~${activityItem}
      • The "activityItem" variable is a code you need to look up in the admin configuration  and specifies what Activity Item you want to retrieve: Go to Admin Configuration -> Activity Item -> then search for you Activity Item and get the according code

Be aware of the Fieldglass APIs ;D

  • A lot of the FG APIs accept only csv in the request body. Make sure you sent the correct value in the correct cell. Use for example Excel if you want to make sure that you entered the correct values underneath the correct header as csv can be hard to read in just plain text and you can easily enter your value in the wrong column
  • They can have spaces in the request URL. Make sure they are correctly encoded by the REST client used
  • Some APIs do not make a full read but only a delta of the underlying entities
    • You can reset the last fetch in Fieldglass if needed for testing
  • In General be very aware of the API syntax as it can be unusual when comparing to the structure of other APIs. For example the syntax of the parameters for the Attachment XML Download  with the "~"  in between. E.g. for the download the parameter differs greatly depending if you want attachments from an Activity Item or a SOW

In conclusion read the documentation very carefully on the business accelerator hub AND the help portal

How to call the Document AI Service:

To get the URL of the we bind the Document AI Service to our application and used the function "getServiceBinding" to  retrieve all the required properties (@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity package)

For starting a job in Document AI you need to set the following headers and make a POST Request:

Header field

Value

Desciption

clientId

<clientId>

You can call this Api to retrieve all client ids

documentType

<documentType>

The type of document being uploaded. Choices: 'invoice', 'paymentAdvice', 'purchaseOrder', 'businessCard', 'deliveryNote', 'resume', 'birthCertificate'
'custom' if you created one yourself

schemaId

<schemaId>

The schema you want to use for your document. (get all schemas with this api)

schemaVersion

<schemaVersion>

The version of your schema

 

Content-Type

Multipart/form-data

 

 

As a response you should receive the jobId this jobId is needed to call the service again later for the result.

In our case we configured the callback from the service, so it calls our application when the job is finished and all results have been extracted. Check this out, to see how this is done. Make sure you have created a configuration key and set "activateDocumentNotifications" to true otherwise the service will not perform a callback. Configure the destination for the callback accordingly.

When the service performs the callback with the job id you can use this to make a GET request to fetch the results of the job. This information is then used to further process the documents and later sent to AI Core.

You can use predefined schemas or you can define your own schemasd. In our case we defined custom schemas. Check out the help portal for schemas

How to call the AI Core

For using the AI Core you can use the provided SDK which fits you best. In our case as we are working with CAP and a NodeJS backend we used the SAP Cloud SDK for AI (JavaScript). We then utilized the Orchestration Service which enables us to quickly change back and forth between the difference models if needed

Set up for side by side extension with Fieldglass:

All APIs of Fieldglass are available in the business accelerator hub and in the help portal

For making HTTP requests to FG you need to have an API Key. Here is a short Joule for consultant explanation on how to do that or check out this help documentation:

Step-by-Step Instructions for API Key Generation:

  1. Access Configuration Manager Dashboard
    1. Sign into SAP Fieldglass using your standard credentials$
    2. Switch to Configuration Manager user: Click your user icon in the upper right corner and select "Linked Accounts"
    3. Navigate to the Configuration Manager dashboard - this provides access to integration tools and administrative functions
  2. Create the API Application Key
    1. Click the "API Application Keys" tile on the Configuration Manager dashboard
    2. Click "New" to create a new API key
    3. Fill out the form with the following required information:
      1. Application Name: Enter a unique, descriptive name (e.g., "SAP Start Integration")
      2. Description: Provide a clear description of the API key's purpose (e.g., "API Key for SAP Start Integration")
    4. Click "Create" to generate the API key
    5. Capture Generated Credentials

After creation, the system will display auto-generated values:

  • Application Key (auto-generated)
  • Client ID (auto-generated)
  • Client Secret (auto-generated)

!!! Important: Copy these values to a secure location immediately, as you cannot retrieve them later !!!

BTP Destination:

Create a BTP destination with the url, credentials and Oauth Url from the API key. Choose "OAuth2ClientCredentials" as Authentication. Don't know how to create a destination? Check this out!

You can now call the SAP Fieldglass APIs over this destination. In case of errors try to call SAP Fieldglass with an REST Client like Postman or Bruno

You can retrieve the destination in CAP for example with the @sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity package with the getDestination function and then make an axios call to Fieldglass

Conclusion:

Congratulations! Using the example of an AI-powered external worker document validation system, you’ve learned how to build a side-by-side extension for Fieldglass with SAP BTP’s AI services. Through this practical use case, you now understand how to leverage SAP Document AI for intelligent document processing, SAP AI Core with its LLMs for automated guideline validation, and navigate the unique challenges of Fieldglass APIs - from CSV request bodies to URL encoding quirks. With this real-world example as your foundation, you’re ready to create your own intelligent automation solutions that enhance Fieldglass 🚀

Special Thanks:
Big thanks to Leo Irudayam for his dedication, expertise and hands-on development that helped bring this PoC to life.
Special thanks also goes to Matthias Beeler for the technical implementation and realization and Sven Breuninger and Kevin Hornung for the Fieldglass expertise that made this PoC possible.

entry.title: Re: Build 8228/8229 Enhancements To Unload/Reload DB Lowe...
entry.content:
This is likely the checkpoint log which is stored at the end of the database file. The checkpoint log only persists while the database is running. When a database is shutdown cleanly, the checkpoint log will have been applied and removed from the file.

The following query may be useful as it reports the size and usage percentage of the checkpoint log:

select DB_PROPERTY('CheckPointLogSize'), DB_PROPERTY('CheckpointLogPagesInUse') 

Looking at the dbinfo -u or sa_table_page_usage procedure should give you an idea where the space is being reported.  

I don't think it is unusual for the database to shrink further on a second rebuild.  It really depends on page utilization percentages for Table and Index pages, as well as free space at the time of the rebuild.

entry.title: Product Definition and Advanced Planning in the Mill Industries
entry.content:
Why Steel, Paper, and Cable Industries Require Specialized Planning

The mill industry—a collective term for sectors like metals and steel, paper, textiles, and cables—is fundamentally different from classic discrete manufacturing. In the automotive industry, the goal is clear: take 10,000 defined parts and build a car. The bill of materials (BOM) is a tree that tapers upwards to a single product.

In the steel industry, it's precisely the opposite. The process begins with a single product—a batch of liquid steel—and the result is a nearly infinite variety of end products: coils, sheets, and plates in thousands of grades, thicknesses, widths, and coatings. This is often called an "inverted bill of materials". Describing and controlling this process requires an enormous number of parameters, known as characteristics.

 

This is where traditional ERP System hits its limits. In many older implementations, the ERP systems served primarily as a financial accounting tool. They only knew about the purchased raw materials and the sold finished products. The entire production process in between—the rolling, annealing, coating—was a "black box," often managed by specialized industry-specific Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES).

In the current global business environment, where on-time-in-full (OTIF) delivery, supply chain transparency, and enterprise-wide optimization are essential for organizational success, relying on a "black box" model is insufficient. It is imperative for companies to integrate their products and processes effectively within a unified central system.

A comprehensive solution involves the strategic definition of products ("What") in conjunction with advanced planning tools ("How"). This blog provides an overview of both aspects, demonstrating how the SAP industry solution for Mill Products—now incorporated into the S/4HANA core—utilizes S/4HANA advances Variant Configuration (aVC) and the sophisticated capabilities of SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for Planning and Scheduling (MPS) - the official solution name for the technical component also known as embedded PP/DS - to address these complex challenges.

 

 Part 1: The Foundation – Strategic Product Definition

The most critical decision in an SAP project for the mill industry is made at the very beginning: How do we model our products? This decision directly impacts nearly every process - sales, logistics, production, quality, controlling, and the entire supply chain planning. This topic is fundamental in nature as well as not new, and it plays a role in every implementation. It has already been excellently presented in this SAP Community Blog.

The Core Question: Configurable vs. Material Variant?

If every product is described by characteristics, why do we need different material numbers at all?

Option 1: The "One-Size-Fits-All" Chaos

Theoretically, one could create a single configurable material (KMAT), for example, "STEEL," and control everything else—grade, thickness, width, coating—via characteristics and rules (object dependencies).

Why this fails: Aside from massive performance and master data problems, the main reason is Controlling. The cost and value flows in the SAP system are based on material numbers. A financial report that merely shows the summarized value of "1,000 coils = X Euros" in one storage location is worthless. Controlling must be able to distinguish between an expensive, high-grade coil and a cheap standard coil in inventory. With a single material number "STEEL," this is impossible.

Option 2: The "Data Graveyard"

The opposite approach would be to create a separate, fully configured material variant that comes with its own material number for every conceivable combination of characteristics (e.g., "STEEL_GRADE-A_0.31MM_WIDTH-X…").

Why this fails: The sheer number of possible combinations is astronomical and unmaintainable. More importantly, it lacks flexibility in production: What happens if the order calls for 0.31 mm thickness, but production yields 0.34 mm? Within tolerance, this would often be acceptable, but it would formally be a different material, blocking the process.

The Best Practice: The "Partially-Configured Material Variant"

The recommended solution is an intelligent middle ground: Material numbers are created that hard-code the important, value-determining, and stable characteristics.

  • Example: A material master is named "HRC_ST37" (Hot Rolled Coil of steel grade St37).
  • How it works: The characteristic "Steel Grade = St37" is predefined and stable in the material master. Characteristics with high variance, such as the exact thickness (e.g., 0.31 mm) or the exact width, remain "open". These flexible characteristics are specified only during sales order entry or production planning.

 

This approach offers a dual benefit:

  1. Controlling: The CO department is satisfied because it can clearly separate the value of "HRC_ST37" from the value of "HRC_ST52" in the same storage location.
  2. Flexibility: Production and planning remain flexible. The material "HRC_ST37" can cover thickness within a tolerance range (e.g., 0.31 mm to 0.34 mm) without requiring a material number change.

Which characteristics are "fixed" in the material number (disaggregation) and which remain "flexible" is the central strategic decision, driven primarily by controlling requirements and production variety.

The Vertical Dimension: Why "Raw Material" and "Finished Good" Are Not Enough

The old "black box" model, where the ERP only knew the raw material and the finished good, is unsuitable for modern control. A global supply chain requires transparency into "Work-in-Process" (WIP).

To plan, control, and valuate material in the SAP system, the system must be able to see that material. Material is only visible in the SAP system if it exists as a material master.

The logical conclusion: We must introduce material master’s at intermediate stages of the process, for example, for "Slab," "Hot Rolled Coil (HRC)," "Cold Rolled Coil (CRC)," etc.

Strategic Criteria: When do I need a new material level?

Defining where to create a new material level (and thus a new Material Master) is a strategic business decision, not just an IT task. It determines the points in the supply chain where the system gains visibility and control.

A new material level should be defined if the process step meets any of the following four criteria:

 

  • Sellable Product: If the intermediate material (e.g., a Slab or Hot Rolled Coil) could theoretically be sold to an external customer or transferred to another internal plant, it must be defined as a distinct material master.
  • Inventory Valuation & Visibility: If the material sits in a storage location (buffer stock) for any ERP-relevant amount of time—meaning more than just a few minutes—and finance needs to track its value, it requires a material master.
  • Decision Points (Re-Allocation): This is often the most critical factor. If a planner needs the flexibility to take a material (e.g., a coil that failed quality inspection for Order A) and re-assign it to a different demand (Order B), that material must exist as an independent, visible object in the system.
  • Subcontracting: If the material leaves the plant for external processing (e.g., sent out for annealing or coating) and returns later, it must be defined as a material master to handle the goods issue and receipt logistics.

 

Each defined material level serves as a "strategic integration point”. These points define exactly where costs are collected, where quality is checked, and most importantly, where a planner can intervene to manage disruptions.

 

Each of these material levels is far more than just a master data record. It is a strategic integration and decision point in the supply chain. It defines where costs are collected, where quality is checked, and—most importantly—where the planner can intervene in the SAP system to react flexibly to disruptions or changes in demand.

 

Part 2: The Implementation – Advanced Planning with S/4HANA MPS

Now that we've clarified the foundation—the "what" and "why" of product definition—the question is "how." How can an SAP system plan with this complex model of partially-configured variants, open characteristics, and multiple production levels?

The clear answer: Standard ERP MRP (Material Requirements Planning) cannot do it. Standard MRP plans at the material number level and is "characteristic-blind" to any features not hard-coded in the material master.

We need a production planning approach beyond the material numbers: SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for Planning and Scheduling, or S/4HANA MPS. This is the strategic, in-core detailed scheduling solution (often called ePP/DS) that integrates the functionality into the S/4HANA core.

Advancing beyond material numbers: Characteristics-Dependent Planning (CDP)

To implement the strategy defined in Part 1, S/4HANA MPS must be operated in a specific mode: Characteristics-Dependent Planning (CDP). You can think of CDP as the "operating system" for S/4HANA MPS, enabling the system to think in terms of characteristics in the first place.

The fundamental difference is:

  • Standard MRP matches material numbers. Demand for "HRC_ST37" is covered by stock of "HRC_ST37."
  • S/4HANA MPS with CDP matches characteristic requirements. A customer demand (e.g., "HRC_ST37," "Thickness 0.32mm," "Color Red") is matched against the characteristic supply of stock (e.g., batches with their classifications) or planned receipts like configured production orders or purchase requisitions.

CDP is the mandatory technical key to making the "partially-configured variant" business strategy plannable. The system can "propagate" or derive characteristics across multiple levels.

To achieve this, three components work together:

  • Advanced Variant Configuration (aVC) is the master data tool used to model the 'partially-configured material' (from Part 1) and its rules.
  • Batch Classification provides the supply-side data.
  • Characteristics-Dependent Planning (CDP) is the planning engine that compares the demand characteristics (from aVC) to the supply characteristics (from the batch classification) to find a valid match.

 

From Advanced Variant Configuration (aVC) to the Production Data Structure (PDS)

The master data for these complex products is modeled in the S/4HANA Core using Advanced Variant Configuration (aVC). You create "Super-BOMs" and "Super-Routings" that contain all possible components and process steps.

To control them dynamically, Object Dependencies are used. Let's look at an example from the paper industry: A finished product TISSUE_PAPER is made from the component PULP. The finished product has the characteristics TP_PLY (number of layers) and TP_COLOR (color). The PULP component also has the TP_COLOR characteristic.

The business logic requires two things:

  • The color of the pulp must match the color of the tissue.
  • The quantity of the pulp depends on the number of layers.

In S/4HANA MPS (with CDP), the color matching is derived automatically, as both materials are set up as configurable. However, for the dynamic quantity calculation, an Object Dependency is stored in the BOM.

This procedure uses a reference characteristic (e.g., PULP_QUANTITY, which points to the BOM quantity field STPO-MENGE) and a formula:

$self.PULP_QUANTITY = $parent.TP_PLY * 0.03

 This formula instructs the system to ignore the static quantity in the BOM and instead dynamically calculate the required pulp quantity by multiplying the number of layers (TP_PLY from the parent material) by a factor (e.g., 0.03 kg per layer).

This entire set of master data (Super-BOM, Super-Routing, and Object Dependencies) is transferred to S/4HANA MPS and stored there as a Production Data Structure (PDS).

Now, when a sales order for 100 units of "3-ply, pink paper" arrives in S/4HANA MPS, the system explodes the PDS dynamically:

  1. It propagates the characteristic "Pink" to the dependent requirement.
  2. It calculates the exact demand: 100 units * 3 layers * 0.03 kg/layer = 9 kg of "Pink Pulp".

Planning with Tolerances: How 'Requirements' and 'Evaluation' enable flexible stock consumption

CDP provides a sophisticated mechanism to handle planning tolerances, primarily by using two different settings for characteristics: 'Evaluation' and 'Requirements'. Understanding this distinction is key to flexible planning.

  • Evaluation: This defines the exact target specification. It is the precise value (e.g., 1.5 meters width) of customer orders and the exact specification that will be sent to production if new manufacturing is required.
  • Requirements: This defines the acceptable tolerance window used only for consuming existing inventory or receipts. It answers the question: "Which batches in my stock are 'good enough' to fulfill this demand?"

 Example:

  1. A customer orders a steel plate with a width of 1.5 meters. This exact value is stored in the Evaluation characteristic.
  2. The business rules state that for this order, any plate between 1.4 and 1.6 meters is acceptable from existing stock. This range is defined in the Requirements characteristic.
  3. The CDP Logic:
    • Step 1 (Stock Search): S/4HANA MPS first searches the inventory (batches) for a match against the Requirements window (1.4m - 1.6m). If it finds a 1.45m batch, it will peg this batch to the order.
    • Step 2 (Production): If no suitable stock is found within the 'Requirements' window, S/4HANA MPS creates a new planned order. Crucially, this order is created using the exact specification from the Evaluation characteristic (1.5m), ensuring production meets the customer's precise request.

 

 

The Core Benefit: Characteristic-Based Pegging

The "golden thread" of this advanced planning logic is pegging: the mechanism that creates a clear, multi-level relationship between a specific demand element (like a sales order) and the specific supply element intended to fulfill it (like a production order or batch).4 This provides planners with critical transparency into how demand is being met.

S/4HANA MPS provides two essential pegging strategies:

  • Dynamic Pegging: Ideal for Make-to-Stock (MTS) scenarios, the system constantly and flexibly recalculates pegging links based on the current planning situation. It always finds the most timely receipt for a requirement, but this link can change.
  • Fixed Pegging: This is the prerequisite for stable Make-to-Order (MTO) and engineer-to-order processes. A fixed peg is a protected, stable link that guarantees a specific supply element is reserved for a specific demand element, providing stable customer confirmations.

This capability reveals the fundamental benefit of S/4HANA MPS and the critical limitation of standard S/4HANA MRP.

The Critical Difference: S/4HANA MPS vs. Standard S/4HANA MRP

The core limitation of standard S/4HANA MRP, including MRP Live, is that it is architecturally "characteristic-blind". Standard MRP is designed to plan only at the material number level.  It is fundamentally incapable of running planning at the batch level or reading the specific characteristics assigned to a batch.

To standard MRP, 100 tons of "HRC_ST37" is simply 100 tons of available stock. It cannot see that this stock is comprised of 10 different batches with unique, non-negotiable characteristics (e.g., "Grade A," "Grade B," different thicknesses, etc.).

In contrast to standard MRP S/4HANA, MPS with CDP solves this problem directly. It performs a characteristic-based netting. The planning run will only create a pegging relationship if the characteristic requirements of the demand (e.g., from a sales order) are matched by the characteristic value assignments of the supply (e.g., the classification on a batch).

This characteristic-based pegging is the engine that enables the entire mill products strategy. It allows a planner to see that a "B-Grade" batch is available and re-allocate it to a B-Grade order. It is what allows the system to see a 10-feet pipe in stock and intelligently peg it to a 9-feet demand, triggering a cutting order. In short, it provides a feasible, realistic plan based on the actual physical and chemical properties of the inventory, not just a material number.

 

Special Function for Mill: Efficiency through Block Planning

A primary cost driver in the mill industry is setup time. Changing the steel grade at the converter, adjusting the width on the paper machine, or switching colors on a coating line can take hours and produce massive amounts of scrap.

Simply planning orders in the sequence, they arrive would be economic suicide. The solution is campaign planning, known in S/4HANA MPS as Block Planning.

 

Block planning is a core function of S/4HANA MPS that allows fixed time windows (blocks) to be reserved on a resource for specific characteristics. Example:

  • Monday, 08:00-16:00: Block for "Red Color"
  • Tuesday, 08:00-16:00: Block for "Blue Color"

Here, the circle closes: S/4HANA MPS uses the characteristic provided by CDP (e.g., "COLOR = Red" from the sales order) to automatically schedule the production order into the correct "Red Block" on Monday. These bundles orders with identical characteristics, drastically minimizing setup times. The strategically defined product characteristic becomes an active control element in operational detailed scheduling.

 

Part 3: Detailed Scenarios and Optimization Tools

Now that we understand the foundation (product definition) and the planning engine (S/4HANA MPS with CDP), let's look at two highly specialized but critical scenarios for the mill industry.

The 'Make-to-Stock (MTS) with Variant Configuration' Scenario

Here we encounter a classic mill problem that perfectly illustrates the strengths of the SAP solution toolkit.

The Business Requirement: A customer orders a product that is almost in stock but requires a minor modification. The classic example from distribution: A lumber dealer has 10-feet pipes as standard stock (MTS). A customer calls and wants to buy a 9-feet pipe.

Why Standard Processes Fail:

  • Standard MTS: The MRP controller would see the 9-feet demand but find no stock (since only 10-feet pipes are on hand). The system would trigger a new production or procurement order for a 9-feet pipe and ignore the 10-feet stock.
  • Standard MTO (Make-to-Order): If the order were entered as MTO, the system would create a production order specifically for this customer. The resulting 9-feet pipe would be "sales-order-specific stock" and could only be delivered to this one customer. This is extremely rigid and prevents the use of warehouse stock.

The Elegant Solution: "MTS with Variant Configuration"

This process, often called "Sales-Order-driven MTS," combines the flexibility of MTO with the efficiency of MTS.

Prerequisites:

  1. The material for the pipe is created as a partially-configured material variant (see Part 1) where the length is open.
  2. The material is batch-managed, and the batch carries the characteristics (e.g., "LENGTH") in addition to its quantity. This is necessary because a single batch might be split into multiple pieces on the same length (e.g. Batch with 10 pieces of LENGTH = 10m has a total quantity of 100m).
  3. Planning occurs in a system that understands characteristics—namely, S/4HANA MPS with CDP.

The Process:

  1. Sales: The salesperson enters a sales order for the material and enters "9 feet" for the “LENGTH" characteristic in the order's configuration screen.
  2. Planning (S/4HANA MPS): S/4HANA MPS (with CDP) activates, sees the characteristic-based demand ("LENGTH = 9 feet"). Simultaneously, it sees the characteristic-based stock (batch with "LENGTH >= 9 feet").
  3. Logic: S/4HANA MPS recognizes that there are no available batches for the pipe with a length of exactly 9-feet but there are batches with a length of >= 9 feet to cover the demand.
  4. Order Generation: Using Planning Heuristics like the Long-Products-Planning (LPP) for the cable Industry or custom industry-specific heuristics MPS can create 'cutting orders'. The key mechanism is that the sales order's configuration (the '9 feet') is passed to the planning engine as a characteristic-based requirement, but not as sales-order-specific stock (MTO). The planning heuristic (e.g., LPP) then finds a suitable batch (10-feet) and creates an anonymous (MTS) production order for cutting, which inherits the '9-feet' configuration.   

The Invaluable Advantage of this Decoupling: The production order creates an anonymous 9-feet pipe for stock (batch with "LENGTH = 9 feet"). If Customer A cancels their order, it's no problem. The 9-feet pipe is in free-use stock (batch). If Customer B calls 10 minutes later asking for a 9-feet pipe, sales can immediately promise and deliver that stock item.

This is impossible with a rigid MTO process. This scenario is the perfect implementation of the flexibility demanded in Part 1 (re-allocation of material) and the reason why characteristic-based planning in S/4HANA MPS is essential for the mill industry.

 

The Modern Customer Promise – Supply-based Confirmation (SBC)

A critical challenge in the mill industry is managing the customer promise (ATP – Available-to-Promise) when inventory is low. If a customer orders a specific product—such as a steel coil with a unique grade and thickness—that is not currently in stock, a standard system would simply show "zero availability" and offer a generic lead time. For high-performance mill supply chains, this lack of precision is unacceptable.

This is also important for online stores, where availability checks can be performed automatically in the background during order entry. This process verifies whether and when an order, including all custom features, can be completed for the customer—that is, whether both the necessary components and the required capacity are available.

In SAP S/4HANA, this gap is closed by Supply-based Confirmation (SBC), a feature within the advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP) toolset. Acting as the successor to the legacy "Capable-to-Promise" (CTP) workflow, SBC integrates the sales check directly with the S/4HANA MPS detailed planning engine.

How the Process Works:

  1. Sales Order Entry: A salesperson enters an order for a configured product (e.g., "Grade A" Steel, "0.3mm" Thickness).
  2. Live Integration Check: The system immediately queries S/4HANA MPS to check current inventory batches for matching characteristics.
  3. Simulation & Planning: If the system finds insufficient stock (or only partial coverage), SBC automatically triggers a live, multi-level planning check for the remaining quantity. Depending on the customization it can validates:
    Capacity: Is there space on the rolling mill, respecting the specific block planning constraints?
    Components: Are the necessary raw materials (e.g., slabs) available?
  4. Temporary Orders: S/4HANA MPS creates temporary planned orders to cover the demand, reserving the necessary capacity and pegging the available stock. Crucially, these orders are non-persistent simulations that exist only while the check is active.
  5. Confirmation: The system calculates a precise delivery date based on this simulation and displays it to the salesperson within seconds.
  6. Conversion: Only when the sales order is explicitly saved do these temporary simulations convert into persistent, fixed planned orders, firmly booking the production slot.

This process allows mill companies to promise reliable delivery dates based on real-time manufacturing reality, rather than static lead times.  Details can be found in this Blog Serie about SAP S/4HANA aATP Supply creation-Based Confirmation

 

Cutting Optimization (Trim)

In the mill industry, specifically for flat products like paper, foil, and steel coils, minimizing waste (trim loss) is often the single largest lever for cost reduction.

Due to the specialized nature of this mathematical problem (geometric optimization) and the availability of various optimization tools in the market, SAP S/4HANA MPS uses a Integration Strategy instead of relying on a standard tool.

 

Architecture: Who Does What?

  • The Core (SAP S/4HANA): Acts as the tactical command center. It manages the demand (customer orders), the supply (master rolls/jumbos), and the execution object (the Trim Sheet Order). SAP provides a standardized "Interface for Industry-Specific Optimizers" to connect external tools.
  • The Ecosystem (Partners): Certified partners (like T.CON with their "TRIM SUITE") provide specific mathematical algorithms. These engines specialize in calculating the complex geometry of slitting patterns, knife changes, and machine constraints.

 

The Integrated Process Flow

The workflow can be designed so the planner never feels like they are leaving the SAP environment, even though an external engine is doing heavy optimization. A potential Workflow can look loke this

  1. Selection (Inside SAP) The planner works directly within the S/4HANA MPS Planning Board. They select a "block" or a group of varied customer orders (e.g., different widths of 7 inches, 9.2 inches) and the available master rolls (e.g., 86 inches wide).
  2. Integration Trigger The planner clicks an integrated "Optimize" button within the SAP interface (depending on SAP Partner Trim solution). The system packages the relevant data (order requirements, stock specifications, quality constraints) and sends it to the partner engine.
  3. The Mathematical Calculation The partner solution calculates the optimal cutting pattern. It optimizes yield by fitting the required customers rolls and sheets onto the master roll in a way that mathematically minimizes waste and setup costs (like moving the cutting knives).
  4. Execution (Back to SAP) The optimized result is sent back to S/4HANA automatically. The crucial outcome is the creation of the so-called Trim Sheet Order (TSO).

 

The Result: The Trim Sheet Order (TSO)

The Trim Sheet Order is the native SAP object that represents the final plan. It is a single production order that contains:

  • Input: The specific master roll (batch) to be consumed.
  • Operations: The detailed cutting instructions.
  • Output: The multiple different finished products (customer coils) and the calculated scrap (trim loss).  

This approach ensures that while the optimization happens externally, the financial and logistical execution remains strictly inside the S/4HANA "System of Record". A demo how it can looks like at a customer can be found here ear Customer: Optimize Cutting Plans with TRIM SUITE 

 

 

Summary and Conclusion

The journey from paper pulp or molten steel to the customer is infinitely more complex in the mill industry than in discrete manufacturing. Mastering requires more than just software; it requires a clear strategy that begins with master data.

The solution is a chain of logical decisions:

  1. It begins with a business-driven product definition (Part 1): the deliberate use of partially-configured material variants (for controlling and flexibility) and the definition of strategic material levels (for planning transparency).
  2. This strategy forces the use of advanced planning, as standard MRP is "characteristic-blind".
  3. The heart of the technical solution is S/4HANA MPS (for detailed planning) combined with CDP (as the "brain" to understand and plan the characteristics).
  4. Building on this, highly developed, industry-specific processes like Block Planning (setup optimization, flexible stock processes (MTS with VC), real-time customer promises (aATP SBC), and specialized optimizations (e.g., cutting stock) can be seamlessly integrated into the standard workflow.

Product definition in the mill industry is not an "IT master data topic"; it is the strategic blueprint for the entire supply chain. Only when this blueprint is drawn correctly can the powerful SAP tools unleash their full potential and transform the complexity of the mill industry into a decisive competitive advantage.

 

 

Appendix

Glossary of Key SAP Mill Industry Terms

The following glossary defines the core concepts discussed in the article, providing direct links to official SAP sources for further reading.

  • Advanced Variant Configuration (aVC): A comprehensive component used to model complex products with multiple options (e.g., steel grades, coil widths). It allows a single material number to represent all variations by using characteristics (features) and dependencies (rules) to define the specific product specifications at the time of order.
    SAP S/4HANA advanced Variant Configuration (SAP.coml)
  • Production Data Structure (PDS)Definition: The blueprint for planning in S/4HANA MPS. It is generated from the core master data (BOMs, Routings, and Object Dependencies) and serves as the technical data structure that the planning engine reads to understand how to produce a specific variant.
    Production Data Structure (PDS) in PP/DS (SAP Community)
  • S/4HANA Manufacturing for Planning and Scheduling (MPS): Also known as Embedded PP/DS (Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling). This is the advanced planning engine built into the S/4HANA core that enables finite capacity planning, heuristic-based scheduling, and the handling of complex material constraints beyond standard MRP.
    SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for Planning and Scheduling (SAP.com)
  • Characteristics-Dependent Planning (CDP): A specialized planning mode within S/4HANA MPS. Unlike standard planning which matches material numbers, CDP matches demand characteristics (e.g., "Width = 1.5m") to supply characteristics (e.g., "Batch Width = 1.6m"). It is the essential engine for the "partially-configured" strategy.
    Characteristics-Dependent Planning (CDP) in S/4HANA (SAP Help Portal)
  • Block Planning: A detailed scheduling function that reserves time segments (blocks) on a resource for products with specific characteristics (e.g., "Paint Line A reserved for Red color on Monday"). It automatically groups orders to minimize setup times and changeover costs.
    Block Planning in PP/DS (SAP Help Portal)
  • Supply-based Confirmation (SBC) / Advanced ATP (aATP): A next-generation availability check. When a sales order is entered, SBC triggers a real-time simulation in the planning engine (MPS) to check if capacity and components exist to produce the item, creating a temporary "feasible" plan to confirm the delivery date immediately
    Supply Creation-Based Confirmation (SBC) (SAP Learning)
  • Trim Sheet Order (TSO): A specialized order object in the mill industry used to execute a cutting plan. It represents the result of a "Trim Optimization" process, where multiple customer orders (smaller widths) are mathematically combined to be cut from a single master roll (jumbo) to minimize waste.
    Partner Solution Example: TRIM SUITE (SAP Store/Partner)

Sources and Additional Information:

  • Planning with Characteristics using SAP S/4HANA DS... - SAP Community
  • SAP Advanced ATP Supply creation-based confirmatio... - SAP Community
  • SAP S/4HANA aATP Supply creation-Based Confirmatio... - SAP Community
  • Product Definition in the Primary Metals Industry - SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Bulgaria EUR Transition_Material inventory balance Mi...
entry.content:
Hi @AdyashaPatra ,

in regards to your question number 2, you can check the app "Material Inventory Values - Balance Summary" (F1422) if it fulfills your needs. It should give you a list of all materials in stock with their quantity and inventory value. If you make sure that you maintain the material prices correctly before posting the goods receipt, the system should automatically post with the right inventory amount into your balance sheet. I hope this helps.

Best regards
Marvin
